description: The bit-phase flip channel randomly applies the Pauli Y operator with probability p. Since Y = iXZ, this error combines a bit flip (X) with a phase flip (Z), making it the third and final single-qubit Pauli error alongside X and Z.

Under a Y error, the state |0⟩ maps to i|1⟩ and |1⟩ maps to -i|0⟩. The global phases (i and -i) are unobservable, but relative phases between superposition components are affected. On the Bloch sphere, Y errors cause contraction toward the y-axis.

Together with bit flip (X) and phase flip (Z), the bit-phase flip (Y) completes the set of Pauli errors. The depolarizing channel applies all three with equal probability, while asymmetric Pauli channels can have different rates for X, Y, and Z errors.

properties.Parameters: p = probability of Y error per gate/time step

physical_examples: Combined bit and phase errors from complex noise processes
Certain crosstalk mechanisms that induce both X and Z rotations
Off-axis rotations that project onto the Y Pauli component
Component of depolarizing noise (alongside X and Z errors)
qem_considerations: Y errors are detected by stabilizer codes that measure both X-type and Z-type syndromes
Pauli twirling converts arbitrary noise into a probabilistic mixture of I, X, Y, Z errors
PEC can correct Y errors given knowledge of the Y error rate
Symmetry verification may detect Y errors if they violate conserved quantities
